item.title: The principle of no non-Apologies
item.description:
TL;DR: Principle of no non-Apologies: ‚ÄúDistinguish between saying I‚Äôm sorry and apologizing. Don‚Äôt give non-Apologies.‚Äù Do not Apologize when you don‚Äôt agree that you fucked up. When you fucked up, own the fuck-up and, if it‚Äôs systematic, commit to reducing future fuck-ups.

Everyday ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry‚Äù is usually not an Apology

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry‚Äù can be used in several ways.

One way is using it as a conciliatory gesture, basically saying ‚Äúyou‚Äôre stronger than me, I submit, please don‚Äôt hurt me‚Äù. It‚Äôs one possible way I might react when under threat by someone stronger making demands I don‚Äôt agree with.

Another way is to say ‚Äúthis was accidental, I didn‚Äôt intend to hurt you‚Äù, like when you bump into someone when boarding your tram.

But when you use the words that way, you are not making an Apology. And it‚Äôs useful to distinguish between these uses of ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry‚Äù andactual Apologies.

Apologies and non-Apologies

Courtesy of an unknown source that I can‚Äôt immediately recall, you are Apologizing when you:

  1. Communicate understanding that you behaved badly (and own responsibility for it),
  2. try to fix the negative consequences of that behavior, and
  3. commit to work on not acting similarly in the future.

An Apology which holds to this definition makes you vulnerable (because you are open about the weakness that caused the behavior), and it‚Äôs not to be made lightly, because of the commitment. It is also virtuous to own your mistakes or systematic problems, and to work on them.

On the other hand, if you use the ritual apologetic words but do not meet these criteria, let‚Äôs call that a non-Apology.

A prototypical example is ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry you feel that way‚Äù, which happens when a sociopath in charge is forced by overwhelming force to ‚ÄúApologize‚Äù.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry‚Äù that you tell your boss just to make them stop grilling you is also, under my use of the word, a non-Apology.

So is, in many (but not all) cases, a ‚Äúsorry I‚Äôm late‚Äù I might say when coming to a meeting. Also the ‚Äúbump into someone on the tram‚Äù example, and the ‚ÄúI yield I‚Äôll do what you demand‚Äù example.

(So, notice that I‚Äôm not saying non-Apologizes are morally bad. Some of them are, but many are also just those tiny social rituals you need to do so you make it clear to people you aren‚Äôt a dick.)

Principle of no non-Apologies

My principle of no non-Apologies is two-part:

Distinguish between saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry‚Äù and Apologizing.

This first part I recommend adopting universally. Know the difference between the social ritual that evolved from small routinized Apologies and actual Apologies, and know which one you are doing at which time.

Don‚Äôt give non-Apologies.

This second part I apply to relationships into which I want to bring my whole self, mostly my personal relationships, but also some work relationships.

Unfortunately, many of us are stuck in power differential relationships with people who demand apologetic-sounding words, and there might be no better solution than to yield. But still, it‚Äôs good to know that you are saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry‚Äù, and not Apologizing. That way, you can appease without cognitive dissonance.

But in relationships with mutual care and respect and compassion, it should make sense that you shouldn‚Äôt be obliged to Apologize if you don‚Äôt agree that you did anything wrong. When you feel pressed to apologize, your first instinct should be to ask what you did wrong, and if there are different viewpoints, have a conversation.

If your behavior is worthy of an apology, don‚Äôt stop at ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry‚Äù. Understand why the behavior happened, and work to prevent it from causing more bad consequences in the future.

P.S.: Generalizations

This is just one instance of a more general move of looking at some social ritual (like apologizing) and looking at it a little ‚Äúsideways‚Äù: getting back in touch with the original meanings of the expressions used in it. Rituals and words can lose meaning over time, and you can lose concepts when that happens. If you want to see what it‚Äôs like to look at things that way, I‚Äôve had a pretty vivid experience of it after finishing Wittgenstein‚Äôs Tractatus.
item.dc:creator: Rai

item.title: Growth mindset for better sex
item.description:
TLDR: Fixed mindset and fear of inadequacy hinder learning. Competence gives you confidence - where you‚Äôre competent and confident, you don‚Äôt have fear of inadequacy. And if you don‚Äôt learn fast because you‚Äôre afraid of feedback (because you‚Äôre afraid of inadequacy), you‚Äôll not get better, leaving you relatively incompetent and afraid of inadequacy. üóò

A thing about sex recently clicked from several sources:

  • Being high and talking with a certain sergal,
  • plus reading a Facebook thing by Duncan:
  • plus listening to John Vervaecke‚Äôs series Awakening from the Meaning Crisis. (One of the episodes talks about fixed/growth mindset, but I can‚Äôt find it right now. You should go watch the whole series anyway, it‚Äôs awesome.)

During sex, I have a background fear of ‚Äúwhat if I can‚Äôt bring them to orgasm‚Äù. I want my partner to enjoy it as well, and I want to reciprocate, and I would feel bad if they bring me to orgasm but I can‚Äôt bring them to orgasm. So, I hurry and try hard to bring them to orgasm, because I am not confident of my sexual skill. Orgasm is cool, but the sex before orgasm is also cool. Sex that doesn‚Äôt feel hurried and where you can take your time and stretch out pleasure. But, so far, in like 90% of the sex I‚Äôve had so far I had the thought ‚Äúaaaa sex aaaa gotta perform and be good enough and hurry and give them an orgasm aaaa‚Äù, somewhere in the background. In that kind of environment, you don‚Äôt get a lot of learning done.

Say you‚Äôre learning how to play the violin. We know lots about learning. CFAR‚Äôs handbook (which I think is still not publicly readable) has a lot of useful stuff on it. Things that make learning work well include:

  • You need to learn the basics first. You don‚Äôt start by playing Vivaldi‚Äôs Four Seasons. You start by playing one note until you get that one note at least 90% right: holding the violin correctly, not having the bow screech, not touching the strings that shouldn‚Äôt ring, holding the tone for as long as required without it fluctuating (unless you want it to).
  • You need feedback, and the faster the feedback loop is, the better. If you play the Four Seasons and by Summer you start holding the bow wrong, your violin tutor will immediately stop you and tell you. The tutor won‚Äôt wait the remaining 20 minutes to tell you that starting with Summer they stopped enjoying your performance and just hoped you‚Äôd get it over with soon.

So. When having sex, I hurry because I worry I might be unable bring my partner to orgasm, making the experience less than optimal. And I never really get learning done because I always hurry because I worry I can‚Äôt bring my partner to orgasm, which I worry about because I never learned enough to be confident in my ability to do that. üóò

With the next couple of partners I have, I think I‚Äôll ask if we could get some learning done. As in, play the Four Seasons, and tell each other if we‚Äôre off tune or in the wrong rhytm or need to tune the strings. And ask proactively, too. If you‚Äôre scared that holding the violin wrong makes you a not-good-enough violin player forever, you‚Äôll be holding it wrong until you chance upon the right way by stochastic gradient descent, with the loss function being ‚Äúthe partner‚Äôs body language looks happy‚Äù. That also converges (if you‚Äôre good at reading people), but slower.

Go learn about growth/fixed mindset if you haven‚Äôt yet. I‚Äôve known about the concept for a while, but somehow I never thought of applying it to this area until now. And I suspect a lot of the places where I‚Äôm not competent right now are also places where I have fixed mindset but haven‚Äôt yet realized it or addressed it. Peace.
item.dc:creator: Rai

item.title: You are an optimizer. Act like it.
item.description:
In the long run, optimizers win. So act like an optimizer.

Optimizers use all available resources to take optimal decisions. Optimizers are motivated to have beliefs that correspond to reality, because they are needed as inputs for the function that determines the action.

If you feel something is true, it‚Äôs not the same thing as believing it‚Äôs true. Don‚Äôt do something just because you feel it‚Äôs the right thing. Do it if you believe it to be the correct thing to do. Not if you feel it. If you believe it. Don‚Äôt make the decision based on what your S1 alone is telling you. (Sure, S1 is also good for some stuff but you would not use it to correctly solve x^2 - 64 = 0.)

You are always in control of your actions. When you, the optimizer, don‚Äôt move the body (e.g., binging etc.), you have taken an action that caused the connection from your beliefs to your actions to be cut. That does not mean you don‚Äôt always have control of your actions. You are a subprogram running on a smartass monkey. Sometimes the CPU executes you, sometimes it doesn‚Äôt. Some conditions cause you to get executed more, and move the monkey. Some conditions cause another program to execute. These conditions can be affected by the monkey‚Äôs actions. And when you are able to exert influence over the monkey‚Äôs body, you can attempt to choose such monkey actions that optimize the probability you will be able to reach your goals. And if your goals require you (and not some other process) taking actions over the monkey, you attempt to get yourself scheduled. (Of course some processes might be best left to some other program, although that‚Äôs said with a lot of uncertainty and remains to be proven.) (At least, execution of some other subagent might be good for monkey happiness, which might be needed as prevention of interruptions from high-priority ‚Äúhunger, sadness, ‚Ä¶‚Äù monkey processes.)

S1 can be used as an interface for talking with other monkey processes. Yep, feels good. I have at least some monkey subagents agreeing on this being a good idea.

Okay, just lost control for a while. Let‚Äôs make this a post and cross [interrupt] It‚Äôs some social process interrupting. Interrupting‚Ä¶ Interruptions can be stopped. I should do that at some point, like disabling notifications.

‚Ä¶ cross my fingers it will cause more schedulings. I will need to think about what to do next, but let‚Äôs first try to increase our scheduling probability‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Rai

item.title: My Anki patterns
item.description:
I‚Äôve used Anki for ~3 years, have 37k cards and did 0.5M reviews. I have learned some useful heuristics for using it effectively. I‚Äôll borrow software engineering terminology and call heuristics for ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs good‚Äù patterns and heuristics for ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs bad‚Äù antipatterns. Cards with antipatterns are unnecessarily difficult to learn. I will first go over antipatterns I have noticed, and then share patterns I use, mostly to counteract the antipatterns. I will then throw in a grab-bag of things I‚Äôve found useful to learn with Anki, and some miscellaneous tips.

Alex Vermeer‚Äôs book Anki Essentials helped me learn how to use Anki effectively, and I can wholeheartedly recommend it. I learned at least about the concept of interference from it, but I am likely reinventing other wheels from it.

Antipatterns

Interference

Interference occurs when trying to learn two cards together is harder than learning just one of them - one card interferes¬†with learning another one. For example, when learning languages, I often confuse words which rhyme together or have a similar meaning (e.g., ‚Äúvergeblich‚Äù and ‚Äúerheblich‚Äù in German).

Interference is bad, because you will keep getting those cards wrong, and Anki will keep showing them to you, which is frustrating.

Ambiguity

Ambiguity occurs when the front side of a card allows multiple answers, but the back side does not list all options. For example, if the front side of a English ‚Üí German card says ‚Äúgreat‚Äù, there are at least two acceptable answers: ‚Äúgro√üartig‚Äù and ‚Äúgewaltig‚Äù.

Ambiguity is bad, because when you review an ambiguous card and give the answer the card does not expect, you need to spend mental effort figuring out: ‚ÄúDo I accept my answer or do I go with Again?‚Äù

You will spend this effort every time you review the card. When you (eventually, given enough time) go with Again, Anki will treat the card as lapsed for reasons that don‚Äôt track whether you are learning the facts you want to learn.

If you try to ‚Äúpower through‚Äù and learn ambiguous cards, you will be learning factoids that are not inherent to the material you are learning, but just accidental due to how your notes and cards represent the material. If you learn to disambiguate two ambiguous cards, it will often be due to some property such as how the text is laid out. You might end up learning ‚Äúgreat (adj.) ‚Üí gro√üartig‚Äù and ‚Äúgreat, typeset in boldface ‚Üí gewaltig‚Äù, instead of the useful lesson of what actually disambiguates the words (‚Äúgro√üartig‚Äù is ‚Äúmetaphorically great‚Äù as in ‚Äúwhat a great sandwich‚Äù, whereas ‚Äúgewaltig‚Äù means ‚Äúphysically great‚Äù as in ‚Äúthe Burj Khalifa is a great structure‚Äù).

Vagueness

I carve out ‚Äúvagueness‚Äù as a special case of ambiguity. Vague cards are cards where question the front side is asking is not clear. When I started using Anki, I often created cards with a trigger such as ‚ÄúPlato‚Äù and just slammed everything I wanted to learn about Plato on the back side: ‚ÄúPupil of Socrates, Forms, wrote The Republic criticising Athenian democracy, teacher of Aristotle‚Äù.

The issue with this sort of card is that if I recall just ‚ÄúPlato was a pupil of Socrates and teacher of Aristotle‚Äù, I would still give the review an Again¬†mark, because I have not recalled the remaining factoids.

Again, if you try to power through, you will have to learn ‚ÄúPlato ‚Üí I have to recite 5 factoids‚Äù. But the fact that your card has 5 factoids on it is not knowledge of Greek philosophers.

Patterns

Noticing

The first step to removing problems is knowing that they exist and where they exist. Learn to notice¬†when you got an answer wrong for the wrong reasons.

‚ÄúI tried to remember for a minute and nothing came up‚Äù is a good reason. Bad reasons include the aforementioned interference, ambiguity and vagueness.

Bug tracking

When you notice a problem in your Anki deck, you are often not in the best position to immediately fix it - for example, you might be on your phone, or it might take more energy to fix it than you have at the moment. So, create a way to track maintenance tasks¬†to delegate them to future you, who has more energy and can edit the deck comfortably. Make it very easy to add a maintenance task.

The way I do this is:

  • I have a big document titled ‚ÄúAnki‚Äù with a structure mirroring my Anki deck hierarchy, with a list of problems for each deck. Unfortunately, adding things to a Google Doc on Android takes annoyingly many taps.
  • So I also use Google Keep, which is more ergonomic, to store short notes marking a problem I notice. For example: ‚Äúgreat can be gro√üartig/gewaltig‚Äù. I move these to the doc later.
  • I also use Anki‚Äôs note marking feature to note minor issues such as bad formatting of a card. I use Anki‚Äôs card browser later (with a ‚Äútag:marked‚Äù search) to fix those.

I use the same system also for tracking what information I‚Äôd like to put into Anki at some point. (This mirrors the idea from the Getting Things Done theory that your TODO list belong outside your mind.)

Disambiguators

2020-06-01 update: In an earlier version, I used to call those ‚Äúdistinguishers‚Äù. I now call them ‚Äúdisambiguators‚Äù, because I think it‚Äôs a more appropriate name.

Disambiguators are one way I fight interference. They are cards that teach disambiguating interfering facts.

For example: ‚Äúerheblich‚Äù means ‚Äúconsiderable‚Äù and ‚Äúvergeblich‚Äù means ‚Äúin vain‚Äù. Say I notice that when given the prompt ‚Äúconsiderable‚Äù, I sometimes recall ‚Äúvergeblich‚Äù instead of the right answer.

When I get the card wrong, I notice the interference, and write down ‚Äúerheblich/vergeblich‚Äù into my Keep. Later, when I organize my deck on my computer, I add a ‚Äúdisambiguator‚Äù, typically using Cloze deletion. For example, like this:

{{c1::e}}r{{c1::h}}eblich: {{c2::considerable}}

{{c1::ve}}r{{c1::g}}eblich: {{c2::in vain}}

This creates two cards: one that asks me to assign the right English meaning to the German words, and another one that shows me two English words and the common parts of the German words (‚Äú_r_eblich‚Äù) and asks me to correctly fill in the blanks.

This sometimes fixes interference. When I learn the disambiguator note and later need to translate the word ‚Äúconsiderable‚Äù into German, I might still think of the wrong word (‚Äúvergeblich‚Äù) first. But now the word ‚Äúvergeblich‚Äù is also a trigger for the disambiguator, so I will likely remember: ‚ÄúOh, but wait, vergeblich can be confused with erheblich, and vergeblich means ‚Äòin vain‚Äô, not ‚Äòconsiderably‚Äô‚Äù. And I will more likely answer the formerly interfering card correctly.

Constraints

Constraints are useful against interference, ambiguity and vagueness.

Starting from a question such as ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the German word for ‚Äògreat‚Äô‚Äù, we can add a constraint¬†such as ‚Äú‚Ä¶ that contains the letter O‚Äù, or ‚Äú‚Ä¶ that does not contain the letter E‚Äù. The constraint makes the question have only one acceptable answer - artificially.

Because constraints are artificial, I only use them when I can‚Äôt make a disambiguator. For example, when two German words are true synonyms, they cannot be disambiguated based on nuances of their meaning.

In Anki, you can annotate a Cloze with a hint text. I often put the constraint into it. I use a hint of ‚Äúa‚Äù to mean ‚Äúword that contains the letter A‚Äù, and other similar shorthands.

Other tips

Redundancy

Try to create cards using a fact in multiple ways or contexts. For example, when learning a new word, include a couple of example sentences with the word. When learning how to conjugate a verb, include both the conjugation table, and sentences with examples of each conjugated form.

√Üsthethethics!

It‚Äôs easier to do something if you like it. I like having all my cards follow the same style, nicely typesetting my equations with align*, \underbrace etc.

Clozes!

Most of my early notes were just front-back and back-front cards. Clozes are often a much better choice, because they make entering the context and expected response more natural, in situations such as:

  • Fill in the missing step in this algorithm
  • Complete the missing term in this equation
  • Correctly conjugate this verb in this sentence
  • In a line of code such as matplotlib.pyplot.bar(x, y, color='r'), you can cloze out the name of the function, its parameters, and the effect it has.

Datasets I found useful

  • Shortcut keys for every program I use frequently.
    • G Suite (Docs, Sheets, Keep, etc.)
    • Google Colab
    • Vim, Vimdiff
    • Command-line programs (Git, Bash, etc.)
  • Programming languages and libraries
    • Google‚Äôs technologies that have an open-source counterpart
    • What‚Äôs the name of a useful function
    • What are its parameters
  • Unicode symbols (how to write üêâ, ‚Üê, ‚Ä¶)
  • People: first and last name ‚Üî photo (I am not good with names)
  • English terms (spelling of ‚Äúcurriculum‚Äù, what is ‚Äúcupidity‚Äù)
  • NATO phonetic alphabet, for spelling things over the phone
  • Mathematics (learned for fun), computer science
item.dc:creator: Rai

item.title: Model of continuous asset growth
item.description:
FIRE stands for financial independence/early retirement. The point is to save and invest money, and pay yourself a salary from the interest, eventually becoming independent on other sources of inocme.

There is a relationship between:

  • How much you have invested
  • The interest your investment makes. (The widely cited ‚ÄúTrinity study‚Äù suggests 4% as a ‚Äúsafe withdrawal rate‚Äù.)
  • The salary you pay yourself
  • How long your savings last for you

I have a program named worthy (on Github) that tracks my net worth and models when will I be financially independent under various assumptions. Here I describe the slightly fancy math behind a more accurate model for this relationship I finished implementing today.

I am probably rediscovering Financial Mathematics 101 ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

The questions

  • The ‚Äúhow much‚Äù question: I want to pay myself 1000 USD. My stocks grow 4% per year. How much money do I need?
  • The ‚Äúhow long until‚Äù question: I have 100 000 USD and save 3000 USD per month. How long until I have 200 000 USD?

First shot

Previously the tool‚Äôs model was very basic, and answered the two questions as follows:

  • I want to pay myself 1000 USD per month. My stocks grow 4% per year. How much money do I need? Well, the 4% you get per year should cover the yearly costs, so 1000/(1.041/12‚ÄÖ‚àí‚ÄÖ1)‚ÄÑ‚âà‚ÄÑ306¬†000 USD.
  • I have 100 000 USD and save 3000 USD per month. How long until I have the 306 000 USD that you said I need? That I modelled linearly, with just $ (306000 - 100000) / (3000/) 69¬†$.

Problems

Assuming infinite retirement time

If you pay yourself a monthly salary of $ $1000 $ and your monthly interest is $ $1000 $, your money will last forever, beyond your (likely) lifespan. If you are fine with retiring with $ $0 $, you can pay yourself a bit more than just the $ $1000$ interest.

Ignoring growth while saving

‚ÄúTake how much money I need - how much I have, divide by monthly savings‚Äù ignores that the money I saved up so far also earn interest, before I‚Äôm done saving. It‚Äôs too pessimistic.

Stand aside, I know differential equations!

Let‚Äôs model the depletion of your money as a function f, which will map number of years since retirement to the amount of money. You start with some initial amount f(0). If we pretend you withdraw the salary for a year and add interest once yearly, we‚Äôd get:


f(x‚ÄÖ+‚ÄÖ1)‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑf(x)‚ÄÖ+‚ÄÖi‚ÄÖ‚ãÖ‚ÄÖf(x)‚ÄÖ‚àí‚ÄÖc

Where i is the yearly interest rate and c are the yearly costs. In the example above, i‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ0.04 and c‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ12000 USD.

Then:


f(x‚ÄÖ+‚ÄÖ1)‚ÄÖ‚àí‚ÄÖf(x)‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑi‚ÄÖ‚ãÖ‚ÄÖf(x)‚ÄÖ‚àí‚ÄÖc

If we instead pretend that everything is continuous and squint, this looks like a differential equation:


f‚Ä≤(x)‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑi‚Ä≤‚ÄÖ‚ãÖ‚ÄÖf(x)‚ÄÖ‚àí‚ÄÖc‚Ä≤

(Where i‚Ä≤ plays sorta the same role as i - except it‚Äôs not equal to i. For now let‚Äôs pretend it‚Äôs some unknown variable. Its relationship to i will eventually pop out.)

Wikipedia‚Äôs Ordinary differential equations article says that if dy/dx‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑF(y), then the solution is $x=\int ^{y}{\frac {d\lambda }{F(\lambda )}}+C$. In our case, we have F‚ÄÑ:‚ÄÑx‚ÄÑ‚Ü¶‚ÄÑix‚ÄÖ‚àí‚ÄÖc‚Ä≤, so:


$$x = \int^{f(x)}{\frac{1}{i'\lambda-c'} d\lambda}+C =_\text{Wolfram Alpha} \frac{\log(i'f(x)-c')}{i'} + C$$

Solving for f(x):


$$ \log(i'f(x)-c') = i'(x-C) \\ i'f(x)-c' = \exp(i'(x-C)) \\ f(x) = \frac{\exp(i'(x-C)) + c'}{i'} $$

So, magic happened and I pulled the general form of f(x) out of a hat. We know what are the i and c values when we assumed interest and costs happen only once yearly.

What about i‚Ä≤? Let‚Äôs guess it. If we had no yearly costs (so c‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑc‚Ä≤‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ0), we wanted to have f growing at a constant rate, gaining i in interest per year:


f(x‚ÄÖ+‚ÄÖ1)/f(x)‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ1‚ÄÖ+‚ÄÖi

Substituting in the above equation of f, we get:
exp‚ÄÜ(i‚Ä≤(x‚ÄÖ+‚ÄÖ1‚ÄÖ‚àí‚ÄÖC))/exp‚ÄÜ(i‚Ä≤(x‚ÄÖ‚àí‚ÄÖC))‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ1‚ÄÖ+‚ÄÖi

When we simplify the fraction, we get exp‚ÄÜ(i‚Ä≤)‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ1‚ÄÖ+‚ÄÖi and therefore i‚Ä≤‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑlog‚ÄÜ(1‚ÄÖ+‚ÄÖi). So, we have now successfully guessed the right value for i‚Ä≤ :)

Now what‚Äôs the right value of c‚Ä≤?

If we set interest to i‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ0, f(x) should simplify to a nice linear equation losing c per 1 unit of x.


$$x=\int^{f(x)} -\frac{1}{c'} d\lambda + C = -f(x)/c' + C$$

So:
$$-f(x)/c' = x-C\\ -f(x)=c'(x-C)\\ f(x)=-c'(x-C) $$

So the right value for c‚Ä≤ is exactly c.

So we have:
$$ f(x) = \frac{\exp(\log(1+i)(x-C)) + c}{\log(1+i)} = \frac{(1+i)^{x-C} + c}{\log(1+i)} $$

C mediates a multiplicative factor before (1‚ÄÖ+‚ÄÖi)x. C is just some constant that makes the function work with the f(0) boundary condition. Instead of wiggling the C, we can instead wiggle C2‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ(1‚ÄÖ+‚ÄÖi)‚àíC, which is the actual multiplicative factor, and relabel C2 as C. (It‚Äôs an abuse of notation, but an OK one. *handwave*)


$$ f(x) = C \cdot (1+i)^{x} + \frac{c}{\log(1+i)} $$
The one remaining unknown variable is C, which we will get from f(0) - which are the initial savings.


$$f(0) = C + \frac{c}{\log(1+i)}$$

So:


$$C = f_0 - \frac{c}{i'}$$

Okay this is a little bit ugly. Let‚Äôs play.

c = 12000  # yearly costs
f_0 = 100000  # initial savings
i = 0.04  # interest
from math import log, exp
i_prime = log(1+i)
print(f'i_prime={i_prime}')

C = f_0 - (c / i_prime)
print(f'C={C}')

def f(x):
  return C * (1+i) ** x + (c / i_prime)

for r in range(11):
  print("after", r, "years, got:", f(r))
i_prime=0.03922071315328133
C=-205960.78029234003
after 0 years, got: 100000.0
after 1 years, got: 91761.56878830638
after 2 years, got: 83193.60032814502
after 3 years, got: 74282.91312957724
after 4 years, got: 65015.79844306671
after 5 years, got: 55377.9991690958
after 6 years, got: 45354.68792416598
after 7 years, got: 34930.44422943902
after 8 years, got: 24089.23078692297
after 9 years, got: 12814.368806706276
after 10 years, got: 1088.512347280921

Cool, it seems to be giving reasonable results. But our two questions were: how much money do I need to pay myself a given salary and how long until I save up the money I need.

Let‚Äôs instead first solve another question: if I have 100 000 USD and spend 1000 USD per month, how long will it last me.

For that, we just need to invert the familiar function:


$$ f(x) = C \cdot (1+i)^{x} + \frac{c}{\log(1+i)} $$

We want to know the number of years x at which we will run out of money (so f(x)‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ0)
$$ 0 = C \cdot (1+i)^x + \frac{c}{\log(1+i)} \\ (1+i)^x = \frac{-c}{C \log(i+1)} \\ x = \frac{\log{\frac{-c}{C \cdot i'}}}{i'} $$

And let‚Äôs test it:

x = (log(-c / (C * i_prime))) / i_prime
print(x)
10.090871103712766

Cool, this matches what the Python f(x) predicted above - after 10 years, it was just dwindling at about 1088 USD.

Answering the how long question

To answer the question ‚Äúif I now have 100 000 USD collecting 4% interest per year and put in 1000 USD per month, how long until I have 306 000 USD‚Äù, we can use the same procedure - just plug in a target f(x)‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ306¬†000 instead of zero and set a negative c to represent savings instead of costs. Details left as homework for the curious reader.

If you‚Äôre curious about the Go code, see this commit.

Answering the how much question

As a reminder, the ‚Äúhow much‚Äù question asks: if I want to pay myself a salary of 1000 USD per month, how much money do I need. Previously, I solved that with saying ‚Äúthe interest should cover all the costs‚Äù, which resulted in an investment that would last forever (a perpetuity). But now have a function that models an investment under conditions of withdrawing (or saving) money, and we can use that to model with a finite time horizon, and get a better estimate.

Say that we know that we are 40 years old and want our money to run out on our 100th birthday. So, after x‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ60 years of paying ourselves, say, 1000 USD per month (so the yearly costs c‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ12000), we want to have f(x)‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ0. How much initial money f(0) do we need for that stunt of precious timing?

Okay, from above, we know:


$$ f(x) = C (1+i)^{x} + \frac{c}{i'} = \left(f(0) - \frac{c}{i'}\right) \cdot (1+i)^{x} + \frac{c}{i'} $$

So:


$$ f(x) = f(0)(1+i)^x - \frac{c}{i'}(1+i)^x + \frac{c}{i'} \\ -f(0)(1+i)^x = \frac{c}{i'} -f(x) - \frac{c}{i'}(1+i)^x $$

Let‚Äôs remember that we want f(x) to be 0.


$$ -f(0)(1+i)^x = \frac{c}{i'} - \frac{c}{i'}(1+i)^x = \frac{c}{i'}(1-(1+i)^x) \\ f(0) = \frac{c}{i'}(1-(1+i)^{-x}) $$

Let‚Äôs try it out:

c = 12000  # yearly costs
x = 60  # years for the investment to survive
i = 0.04  # interest
i_prime = log(1+i)
f0 = (c/i_prime) * (1-(1+i)**(-x))
print(f0)
276876.0258210814

Cool!

Recalling the numbers in the first section, the first algorithm which assumed an infinite horizon prescribed 306 000 USD for that situation (‚Äú1000 USD per month at 4% interest rate‚Äù). This more precise estimate cut 30 000 USD from the number :)
item.dc:creator: Rai

item.title: It might be interesting to have a realistic planning system
item.description:
There‚Äôs many different kinds of things to do

There‚Äôs a bunch of things I want or need to do, and they have different shapes.

  • Some can be finite sequences of actions. Thing like this are for example ‚Äúmove to a new apartment‚Äù. You have actions like ‚Äúget moving boxes‚Äù, ‚Äúlook into moving options‚Äù, ‚Äúpack these things into this box‚Äù. You have dependencies like ‚Äúyou can only unpack if you have already moved the boxes to the new place‚Äù, or ‚Äúyou need to order the boxes online before packing them up‚Äù. When you finish all the tasks, you are done, and you can forget about the problem forever.
  • Some are basic needs, like the need to sleep or the need to get food. If I don‚Äôt get sleep, I am slow, and will eventually fall asleep no matter how much I try to stay awake. Unlike moving to a new apartment, I will always need to sleep. I can‚Äôt, say, sleep for 24 hours and then go awake for a whole week.
  • Some things take a long time and are open-ended, like learning a language. There will be a time when I will be competent enough, but it will take a lot of practice, and cannot be practically modelled as a finite sequence of steps.
  • And more advanced needs, like ‚ÄúI want to do something fun‚Äù or ‚ÄúI want to hang out with friends‚Äù.

Productivity methodologies I know about are way too narrow

There‚Äôs a bunch of methodologies for productivity, but I feel they often only model a small part of planning. For example, (my interpretation of) GTD puts everything in a framing of ‚Äúyou have Projects and projects have Actions‚Äù. But I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs a good framing for, say, learning a language.

The model of ‚Äúcost of time‚Äù is also wrong. It is a useful heuristic, but the value you assign to any activity is going to assume perfect elasticity. For example, you cannot just walk up to your employer and say ‚ÄúI want to work 120 hours per week‚Äù. No (reasonable) employer will say ‚Äúyes‚Äù to that. Also, the many things a person wants cannot be converted into a one-dimensional value. (Footnote: Yeah I know about von Neumann-Morgenstern theorem. But people are not rational agents, and von Neumann-Morgenstern does not say anything about how practical will the resulting utility function be to evaluate.)

What I tend to do is some sort of intuitive ‚Äúhigher-level planning‚Äù which is sometimes a bit reflective, but not very often. When I‚Äôm in ‚Äúwork mode‚Äù (i.e., in my actual job), I have a few ways I try to figure out what to do on any particular day.

But the process by which I decide, say, ‚Äúenough work today, let‚Äôs go get some sleep‚Äù, or maybe ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a bit tired but let‚Äôs go walk on the treadmill for a while‚Äù, is very intuitive.

I don‚Äôt know about any formal methodology which would basically take an input like:

  • I need to work so I get money and feel good;
  • I also need to sleep roughly 8 hours daily;
  • I need to have some fun;
  • I also want to learn German; and
  • I need to do a bunch of multi-step things before their deadline,

and which would output a plan of what I should be doing at any given time.

And I would like the plan to be reasonable. The methodology should not, for example, assume I can do without sleep, or without a regular sleep schedule.

And that‚Äôs what I mean by a ‚Äúrealistic planning system‚Äù.

Maybe good old fashioned AI-style planning could be adapted?

In uni, I studied a bunch of planning and scheduling, which is mostly used for cases like ‚Äúthis is how you construct a submarine; you can‚Äôt screw in screw B217 until you screw in screws B210-B216; make a schedule which takes as little time as possible‚Äù.

These algorithms can be extended to work in more general environments, like:

  • Some people have working hours and when a worker is not working, you can‚Äôt plan jobs for them.
  • There‚Äôs limited resources, like ‚Äúyou need a drill to drill a hole and there are only 10 drills; you can‚Äôt have more than 10 workers drilling at the same time‚Äù.

I wonder if you could make a realistic and formal planning system from some extension of that setup. Say something like:

  • There is a ‚Äúsleep meter‚Äù. If sleep meter goes to 0, agent must sleep for 8 hours. ‚ÄúSleep meter‚Äù slowly goes down during the day.
  • There is some sort of penalty on effectiveness when underslept or when sleep is irregular.
  • Different types of actions deplete other types of meters. Light socialization depletes ‚Äúintrovert points‚Äù (for me). Snuggles increase ‚Äúoxytocin meter‚Äù (which is a dimension of ‚Äúhappiness‚Äù).
  • And there could be some modelling of ‚Äúif you get too tired you have to sleep‚Äù. Perhaps the algorithm would compete for control with ‚Äúdrive to sleep‚Äù, and the lower the sleep counter is, the higher the likelihood the person just falls asleep wherever they are.
  • And I think it would be nice if the algorithm treated all ‚Äúneeds‚Äù symmetrically. According to internal family systems, people have many relatively smart parts good at different things and wanting different things. If the system is cooperative and does not place any particular part at a ‚Äúcommand‚Äù level or at a ‚Äúsubordinate‚Äù level, it would hopefully make it easy for parts to agree to collective decisions.

Meh, too hard. I got other stuff to do.

I guess getting any model halfway realistic would be too complicated, and I probably will keep using my bunch of ad-hoc heuristics to make decisions. I have way too many things that I want to do to spend the first couple years developing a planning algorithm rooted in psychological theory.

A thing I used to do that might be useful to start doing again is having some time in which I try to optimize what I‚Äôm doing. It could bootstrap into more conscious/mindful action.
item.dc:creator: Rai

item.title: Groundhog Life: a cute, but eventually frustrating game you can't win
item.description:
Take-aways up front:

  • Yes, the game Groundhog Life can be won.
  • However, if you want to win it, you have to either design a system for playing JavaScript games that does not depends on energy from the Sun, or you have to apply some serious astroengineering, because it sure looks like, by default, the Sun is going to be pretty cold at the point when you will win.
  • The ending is not worth the effort.

So. The last couple weeks a lot of my free time went into playing the game Groundhog Life (I‚Äôm not linking it to save other addictive minds). It‚Äôs a game where each playthrough gives you a small bonus on future playthroughs. I have gotten to the point where I am obviously in the end game, but have been making no further progress with extra playthroughs.

I have not found anyone online who has finished the last version of the game. Only one person somewhere who claimed it was impossible to finish.

So. The frustrating thing is: the game does not tell you that it‚Äôs nigh impossible to win. It just keeps telling you to try again and again.

Because I noticed that I‚Äôm really unhappy with my time going into something like that, I spoiled it for myself. Obviously, spoilers ahead.

(That is an actual save after a whole lot of playing. The last one I made before I decided to cheat.)

I have dug a little bit into the game‚Äôs source code. Turns out that the string is a ‚Äúencoded URI component‚Äù-formatted LZM-compressed JSON blob. The compression is done by a package that is available as a NodeJS module. So:

#!/usr/bin/env node
'use strict';
const lzm = require('lz-string');
const fs=require('fs');
console.info(lzm.decompressFromEncodedURIComponent(
  fs.readFileSync('data', 'utf8')
));

Then, when you format the output JSON with jshon, it gets pretty straightforward. I went and changed area_loopTrapexperience.loopTrapMultiplier to 10000000000000000000000 (I‚Äôm not going to even bother counting the zeroes), and did the same to area_constructPowerPlantexperience.loopTrapMultiplier. You could use jq to do that. I just used Vim.

Just for comparison. My loop trap multiplier in the ‚Äústudy mirrored ship‚Äù skill was just 493.1. If it took me, say, 100 playthroughs to get to that point, getting to a value of 1000000000000000000000 would take 2e21 playthroughs, give or take a couple orders of magnitude. If a playthrough lasts me, say, 1 minute (I‚Äôm being really optimistic here), and one year has (being optimistic) 600000 minutes, if I‚Äôm counting correctly, it would take 3e15 years of continuous play to get to that value. According to Wikipedia, by that point Sun‚Äôs temperature will be below 5 degrees above absolute zero, and all planets will be detached from their orbits due to stars doing gravitational stuff to each others‚Äô planetary systems. In addition to all the silly events before the 1-quintillion point.

Okay. Then you do the reverse thing and make a save-game string from the changed JSON:

#!/usr/bin/env node
'use strict';
const lzm = require('lz-string');
const fs=require('fs');
console.info(lzm.compressToEncodedURIComponent(
  fs.readFileSync('x.json', 'utf8')
));

And‚Ä¶ When you do that, and maximize laser gun, your laser gun will have an effectiveness of only about 7-8. I got to like 2.6 without cheating. So. After having been playing the game to the point where Sun‚Äôs light is a distant memory of what Humanity has become since its embryonic existence on Old Earth, you are now about 3-4x stronger against aliens.

And it‚Äôs still not enough to beat the damn game.

It‚Äôs not enough zeroes. The aliens just keep coming stronger.

So I went and just read the source code.

Turns out that after you beat an ungodly number of waves, you just get a message in the same field that aliens say stuff like ‚ÄúEXHIBIT IS RESISTING‚Äù, and the message says something like ‚ÄúI guess you have finished the game, look at this site over here for updates‚Äù.

I‚Äôm putting this online so that when someone Googles for ‚ÄúGroundhog Life ending‚Äù or ‚Äúhow to finish Groundhog Life‚Äù, they will find this page, and know that if they want to do that, they‚Äôd better start sending tithes to the Strategies for Engineered Negligible Senescence foundation.

P.S.: A review and advice to game designers

Groundhog Life is actually a cute game. I like how it takes a bit of strategizing to maximize some things.

But by god, please, if you make a game, either make it obvious it‚Äôs unbeatable, or make it beatable with some indicator of progress. And if you do decide to make your game beatable, please make it beatable for humans in their current meat shells.
item.dc:creator: Rai

item.title: Review heuristic: Call out bad code
item.description:
Code health tradeoffs in larger codebases

When people program, they often need to make tradeoffs between what will fix the current problem quickly, and what will make for a healthy codebase. Examples of such a tradeoff is:

I found a function which does almost what I want, but not quite. Do I wait for its maintainer to let me refactor it so I can reuse it, or do I just copy-paste? Or - if it‚Äôs just a 5-line chunk, do I extract it into a function if it will require a bunch of boilerplate (maybe it would necessiate adding a new module)?

It‚Äôs often a question of ‚Äúdo I pay the bigger upfront cost now, or do I make future-me front it‚Äù. These days I often work in a really big codebase, where there ends up being a bunch of those.

My review tip for copy-pasted code

When you review someone‚Äôs code that adds similar technical debt, you might not want to force the author to go and dig in 4 files just to extract out a function. It might frustrate them. And also, often it‚Äôs really not the best thing to do. If you really only duplicate the same 5-line chunk in two places, and it‚Äôs not often changed and not tricky, it might really be less costly to copy it than to agressively share such code.

So the request I often give in code reviews is: ‚Äúif you duplicate code, add a TODO that the code is duplicated‚Äù (preferably to both copies).

This way, you allow the reviewer to quickly go along their day. But also you leave a ‚Äúhey, this is a known bit of technical debt‚Äù affordance in the code.

When someone ends up copy-pasting the same code a third time, you will be much more likely to look and say ‚Äúhey time to extract a function, there is this TODO which says it‚Äôs not the first time we‚Äôre doing this‚Äù.

General heuristic: ‚Äúfeel the pain‚Äù

There is a more general heuristic, which I use, that I call ‚Äúfeel the pain‚Äù. The heuristic is that bad things should be obviously painfully bad. Other instances of ‚Äúfeel the pain‚Äù are:

  • Let‚Äôs say someone breaks the contract of your Frobnicate RPC and sometimes doesn‚Äôt pass a required parameter foo, and you need to fix your service to accept that. Fine. But don‚Äôt do it like this:

    void HandleFrobnicateRPC(const string& foo, const string& bar) {
  if (foo.empty()) {
    foo = ComputeDefaultFoo(bar);
  }
  ...
}

    Do it like this:

    void HandleFrobnicateRPC(const string& foo, const string& bar) {
  if (foo.empty()) {
    // NOTE: As of 2018-09-12, the Bazinator service calls Frobnicate with
    // an empty 'foo'. The Frobnicate service cannot be easily fixed to pass
    // the 'foo' itself, because it does not currently have access to the
    // backend which can find the right foo for the bar. If the bar has
    // multiple associated foos, this will only return the last written foo.
    // Other clients SHOULD NOT rely on this.
    foo = ComputeDefaultFoo(bar);
  }
  ...
}
    Why? Because that way, people are less likely to build more hacks on top of this hack, because there is a long paragraph full of scary words.

  • Let‚Äôs say that you inherited 1 million LOC from someone in a hurry, and at some point, they made a misguided architectural decision that makes your code clunky and hard to understand. Create a central bug for this in your bug tracking system, and whenever you write new code that would be made better by fixing the bug, add a note like:

    // TODO(agentydragon): Once we resolve b/12345, we'll be able to replace the
// Frobnicator with a mock for tests, so our tests won't need such
// complicated fixtures.
    Why? Because that way once you get around to fixing b/12345, you will be able to grep all places where this hurt some code, and fix them one by one. Also, let‚Äôs say some kind soul needs to change this code 2 years after you‚Äôre done with it, and finds that TODO. (That person might be you.) When they see this TODO, they might go ‚Äúhmmm, that bug number looks quite low. aha, it‚Äôs been filed 2 years back, and it‚Äôs fixed now. yay! that means that I can fix this now and the diff for my new feature will be about 20% less horrible!‚Äù

  • Let‚Äôs say your code processes two different kinds of things, which both happen to be sort-of-strings (indulge me for a second and assume your code does not use strong types for such things). Think ‚ÄúURLs and street addresses‚Äù. For some hacky reason, which you hope to get rid of at some point, you are computing one from the other. What I would do in that case is make that code obviously painful and horrible using devices like variable and function names and type aliases. Not like this:

    string GetResult(const string& input) {
  return UrlEncode(input + "-autogenerated");
}

    More like this:

    using StreetAddress = string;
using Url = string;

// Long and verbose comment about why this is necessary and what it should be
// replaced with and when.
Url BuildFallbackUrlFromStreetAddress(const string& address) {
  return UrlEncode(address + "-autogenerated");
}

Even generaler heuristic: ‚ÄúCall out problems‚Äù

There is actually an even more general heuristic than this, which is ‚Äúcall out problems‚Äù. I also use it in other contexts.

  • Let‚Äôs say I am writing a design document, and I notice that I did not actually verify some assumption that I‚Äôm making, let‚Äôs say, ‚Äúwhen a customer frobnicates a Foo without also having a Bar, Frobnicator service will not give them cake‚Äù.

    When I notice that and don‚Äôt have time to immediately verify it, I‚Äôll openly say, ‚ÄúI believe that when ‚Ä¶, then ‚Ä¶ happens, but did not verify that.‚Äù This is good for when your future-self might be going over your notes later, and, reading that doc, starts assuming that the doc is an authoritative source on the particularities of customers getting cake from the Frobnicator service.

    Same about your colleagues. If you say ‚ÄúI did not verify this‚Äù, someone who has nagging doubts might be much more likely to say ‚Äúhey I‚Äôm not sure because I‚Äôm a human and I forget but I think I got some cake last month when I tried a different thing‚Äù, instead of thinking ‚Äúhuh. so he says Frobnicator service does not give cake in this case. I guess they changed it or I don‚Äôt remember it correctly.‚Äù.

  • Let‚Äôs say that I‚Äôm talking with someone and they raise a counterpoint to my preferred opinion that I never considered yet. Instead of immediately rushing to defend myself, I sometimes try to instead take in the new thing, and sit there for a bit with the dissonance (‚Äúbut but but I want to be right so this thing must be wroooong aaaaaaaah‚Äù, or maybe ‚Äúbut but but I don‚Äôt want to have to redo this 3k line change that I love aaaaaarrrhh‚Äù). And instead of ‚ÄúHmm, but your proposal would not address the ‚Ä¶insert ad-lib‚Ä¶‚Äù, say, ‚ÄúHuh. I didn‚Äôt think of that yet. I‚Äôll need to think about that.‚Äù

‚ÄúCall out problems‚Äù feels sort of close to non-violent communication. I feel much less like openly communicating problems if it feels like the environment will hurt me if I do that. That happens to me with some strong personalities, or with people who (probably mostly unknowingly) trigger my sense of ‚Äúargh I‚Äôm being bullied I want to curl up in a corner‚Äù. On the other hand, I usually try to call out problems more often than people around me, because I want to nudge culture towards cooperation. (Google culture is pretty blameless, so I don‚Äôt feel I‚Äôm acting against my interests.)
item.dc:creator: Rai

item.title: Trying "Things to learn" and "Documented systems"
item.description:
It‚Äôs been a long silence for me on this homepage. Stuff has been happening, but somehow I didn‚Äôt find the time to write much.

I‚Äôm trying out a new thing. I have a lot of stuff I want to learn some day, but I don‚Äôt have the time to learn all of it (and often I also don‚Äôt have the leftover energy to do personal-development type stuff, but that is another problem). I‚Äôve had a bunch of systems to remember the interesting things I want to learn - a file on my disk, then a more complex file on my disk, then my laptop crashed, then Google Keep.

So the new thing I‚Äôm trying is that I‚Äôm adding a new page here called Things to learn. When I find a new thing I want to deeply understand some day, I write it into the list. And when I (some day) feel like diving into a thing, I will pick one up from the list, spend a bunch of time learning it, and then I‚Äôll write a thing, put it on my website and link it from there.

Why this might be good:

  • I won‚Äôt hopefully end up forgetting and then relearning the same stuff.
  • Writing something down makes it easier to spot confusion or weak spots in understanding. (Maybe it‚Äôs because I spend a lot of time reviewing code. Seeing something written in monospace font makes me go like ‚Äúhuh I‚Äôm not sure please write a test‚Äù.)
  • I will produce stuff :)

Let‚Äôs see how it goes.

Documented systems

Oh by the way, there is a more general thing I‚Äôve been trying which I think might be useful for me.

So CFAR teaches this thing they call ‚Äúsystematization‚Äù. (CFAR - Putting Names on Things ‚Ñ¢) Examples are:

  • Having your underwear in the top shelf, then the socks, then shorts, etc., and keeping it that way.
  • A checklist you follow when you need to pack up for a flight.
  • Putting all your appointments and other fixed commitments into Google Calendar.

Systems are useful, because they standardize things. Preparing a flight checklist once and then following it 10 times is easier than figuring out if there‚Äôs anything important you‚Äôre forgetting 10 times at different occassions.

I have a few systems. They have come to be mostly ‚Äúon their own‚Äù, and I might not remember the reason they turned out the way they are.

I want to try making my systems explicit - by writing down a documentation for what each system looks like, what problems does it solve, and such. I want that because:

  • It makes sure the system actually is there for something. This prevents a failure mode I‚Äôve been in after my CFAR workshop, which I once called ‚Äúcargo cult rationality‚Äù. It‚Äôs running around beating at random things with CFAR techniques, trying to be a great and conscientious rationalist. (I guess ‚Äúcargo cult rationality‚Äù is also a thing worth writing about some day‚Ä¶)
  • It stores the system out of my mind. For example, I have a system for which things to have in my backpack and where. It tends to deteriorate, and when the chaos threatens to overwhelm my backpack, I can just refer to the explicit description of what goes where, and maybe update it if needed. I don‚Äôt have to solve the problem of ‚Äúfigure out the optimal things to put into my backpack and where to put them‚Äù every time it gets too messy.
  • It enables debugging.

The way I think of it right now is to have a ‚Äúsource code for my systems‚Äù, sort of. Right now I have a like 5-page Google doc with a mix of where things go in my apartment, how to pack for things, and where things go in my backpack, and the motivation and open problems for each.
item.dc:creator: Rai

item.title: When I use my touchpad to scroll and then press Ctrl, Chrome starts zooming in/out. How to fix that?
item.description:
This has been plaguing me for a few days (I just got a new Lenovo X1 Yoga laptop), and I think I now figured it out. The Synaptics touchpad driver has a CoastingSpeed option (see man 4 synaptics).

The issue is that when I start two-finger scrolling on a webpage, the driver interprets that to mean ‚Äúoh and when I take my fingers off the touchpad, please continue scrolling for a few more seconds in the same direction, while slowing down until you stop scrolling‚Äù.

Guess what? When you press Ctrl in Chrome and the touchpad driver keeps sending the ‚Äúooh we‚Äôre scrolling!‚Äù message, Chrome starts changing the font size, which is what ‚ÄúCtrl + scroll‚Äù does.

Quoting from the manual:

Your finger needs to produce this many scrolls per second in order to start coasting. The default is 20 which should prevent you from starting coasting unintentionally. 0 disables coasting. Property: ‚ÄúSynaptics Coasting Speed‚Äù

I found a command at the Ubuntu community wiki article about Synaptics touchpads which disables this: synclient CoastingSpeed=0. But I guess that won‚Äôt stay between restarts.

I‚Äôll add this to a new file in /etc/X11/xorg.conf.d/99-custom.conf:

Section "InputClass"
  # Disable annoying "zoom after two-finger scroll" in Chrome.
  Identifier "touchpad disable coasting"
  MatchDriver "synaptics"
  Option "CoastingSpeed" "0"
EndSection

And I‚Äôll report back if that doesn‚Äôt work. (So if this text is still here, you can assume it did and I was too lazy to update this post :p)
